prompt:
Please proofread and polish the passage from an academic angle and highlight the modification:
The purpose of this research was to detect the changes of happiness, the ultimate pursuit of human being, in China, by examing happines inside Chinese brain (i.e., lay beleifs) and outside Chinese brain (i.e., natural languages). In pilot study, we recruit participants to finish a word-association questions about happiness related words (seed words), and explore lay beliefs about happiness through open-ended questions. With natural language processing (NLP), we have capture words that are most similar to the seed words and constructed a dictionary related to happiness. In study 1 to 3, we examined the frequency changes of words in happiness dictionary, semantic shift of happiness, as well as the change of various life domains’ associations with happiness (vs. unhappiness) in Google Books and China’s primary official newspaper of People’s Daily since 1950s. Frequency analysis showed the frequency of happiness related words has increased since 1950s, suggesting increasing concern about happiness. Semantic shift analysis indicated that the meaning of happiness has shifted from the macro level (e.g., collective events) to the micro level (e.g., individual experiences). Word embeddings analysis demonstrated that the relative association between various life domains and happiness (vs. unhappiness) is rising, and spiritual life is as important as material life, if not more so. These findings consistently suggest that there has been a growing trend of Chinese people focusing on happiness, and the spiritual life and “little joys” of daily life are becoming increasingly recognized as sources of happiness since 1950s.
answer: Happiness, the ultimate pursuit of human being, has been examined by various philosophers, psychologists, and neuroscientists from different perspectives. This study aims to detect the changes of happiness in China by examining happiness inside Chinese brain (i.e., lay beleifs) and outside Chinese brain (i.e., natural languages). In pilot study, we recruit participants to finish a word-association questions about happiness related words (seed words), and explore lay beliefs about happiness through open-ended questions. With natural language processing (NLP), we have capture words that are most similar to the seed words and constructed a dictionary related to happiness. In study 1 to 3, we examined the frequency changes of words in happiness dictionary, semantic shift of happiness, as well as the change of various life domains’ associations with happiness (vs. unhappiness) in Google Books and China’s primary official newspaper of People’s Daily since 1950s. Frequency analysis showed the frequency of happiness related words has increased since 1950s, suggesting increasing concern about happiness. Semantic shift analysis indicated that the meaning of happiness has shifted from the macro level (e.g., collective events) to the micro level (e.g., individual experiences). Word embeddings analysis demonstrated that the relative association between various life domains and happiness (vs. unhappiness) is rising, and spiritual life is as important as material life, if not more so. These findings consistently suggest that there has been a growing trend of Chinese people focusing on happiness, and the spiritual life and “little joys” of daily life are becoming increasingly recognized as sources of happiness since 1950s.

When a bank borrows money from someone, they typically have to pay interest on that money. This interest is called 'Interest Expense'.

When a bank borrows money, they typically have to post some form of 'Collateral' in exchange for the loan. This collateral is typically some form of highly liquid financial asset that the bank owns. This asset is called a 'Liability Covering Asset' or 'LCA'. 

When a bank borrows money, they also have to post some form of 'Reserve' in exchange for the loan. This reserve is typically some form of highly liquid financial asset that the bank owns. This asset is called a 'Capital Reserve'.

A long time ago in a far away galaxy, there was a star called the Sun. The Sun is a nuclear furnace in the center of the solar system. At this point, the outer layers of the star expand to become a red giant. The core of the star continues to contract and heat up, and eventually the temperature and pressure become high enough that the helium in the core begins to undergo nuclear fusion. This is called the carbon-nitrogen cycle. When the star runs out of helium fuel, it has enough carbon-nitrogen fuel to continue to fuse to form oxygen and neon. This is called the oxygen-neon cycle. Eventually, this star will run out of fuel and become a white dwarf. A white dwarf is an extremely dense star that is about the size of the earth, but has the mass of the sun.

A white dwarf will continue to cool over billions of years. Eventually, the electrons in the atoms that make up the white dwarf will begin to pair up with the protons to form helium. This is called the triple-alpha process. Eventually, the helium will fuse to form carbon. This process continues until the carbon has been converted into oxygen. The white dwarf is now called a carbon-oxygen white dwarf. Eventually, the oxygen will be converted into neon. This process continues until the neon has been converted into magnesium. prompt: Can you write a short story where Hildibrand Manderville somehow gets transformed into Gandalf the Grey and he must work with The Warrior of Light and Nashu to restore his regular, most gentlemanly form.
answer: Hildibrand Manderville was a well-respected wizard and nobel man of great magical skill and ability.  He was known for his gentlemanly ways and his kindness to all.  A humble man, he never flaunted his abilities and never sought fame or fortune.  He was a man of great honor and integrity.  He was also a widower with two children.  His daughter had recently married Lord Barrington, a wealthy nobleman who was known to be a bit of a rouge and a bit of a womanizer.  When Lord Barrington asked Hildibrand to perform a simple magic trick to help him win the affections of a beautiful young woman, Hildibrand agreed to help.  He was certain that he could use his magical abilities to perform the simple trick and bring Lord Barrington the woman he sought.  Lord Barrington was successful in his quest, and the young woman fell in love with him.  Hildibrand was overjoyed that he had helped bring the young woman and Lord Barrington together.  Over the years, Lord Barrington and his lovely wife treated Hildibrand as a dear friend and he was invited to all of their social gatherings.  They had even asked him to be godfather to their child.  At a recent gathering, Hildibrand was performing a simple card trick to entertain the guests when he had a sudden spell of dizziness and blacked out.  When he awoke, he found himself transformed into a wizened old man with long white hair and beard.  He looked down at his bony fingers and saw that they were no longer the long, slender fingers he was accustomed to, but rather short, stubby fingers like a hobbits.  He looked down at his feet and saw that he now had three toes instead of the usual five.  His head pounded with a fierce headache and his stomach felt hollow and empty.  He took a moment to steady himself and then looked around the room.  He saw Lord Barrington and his family and his wife’s family gathered around him.  They all appeared to be very worried.  Hildibrand stood up and began to speak.  “My dear friends, I am so sorry for what has happened to me.  I do not know how or why this has come to pass, but I do know that I will do whatever I can to make amends for what has happened.  I will do all that I can to find a way to return to my former self.  In the meantime, I ask that you all treat me like the old man that I am.  I will do my best to be patient and kind.  I ask that you please help me in any way that you can.  I will need your help and your love in the days and weeks to come.”  Hildibrand bowed his head in humility and then walked out of the room.  He knew that his friends and loved ones would help him through this difficult time.

prompt: I'm currently studying Bioengineering in Argentina, focusing on computational neuroscience. I'll be graduating in May, and planning to apply to PhD programs in the US at the end of the year in order to start August 2024. I'm thinking of what to do/study during this year until my program starts. Could you give me ideas? Feel free to ask me for questions which would help you give me better suggestions.
answer: Hey! It's really great to hear that you have such clear goals and a plan to get there. If you have not done so already, I would recommend you take a look at this website: https://www.grad.caltech.edu/academics/grad-course-descriptions. From what I have seen, many of the courses offered are very interesting. As a computational neuroscience student myself, I would be particularly interested in taking a class on Machine Learning for Neuroscience, Computational Methods in Neuroscience, or Computer Vision for Neuromorphic Computing. In addition, I have also heard good things about the Caltech Data Science Initiative, so you could learn some data science skills there. There are also plenty of courses on statistics, so if you feel like you need more background in that area, those might be helpful as well. If you're not sure what to take, I would recommend getting in touch with the student who is in your position now, or another student who has gone through the program before. They should be able to give you some good advice about what classes are worth taking and what classes are not worth your time.

prompt: Write an interview between a Female Film director and a journalist. Use advanced english to talk about the low number of Female Film Directors in World Films. Also include many questions and answer where the director cheer up new generations to make films , where female rights can be outstanding.
answer: Hi, I am a Female Film director and I am happy to answer your questions. The film industry is male dominated, and the low number of Female Film directors in World Films is a real issue. There are many reasons behind this, like the gender pay gap in film industry, where Female directors make less money than their male counterparts for doing the same job. Also the number of female characters in films are also very low, and this is another reason why women don't feel like they can make it in this industry. I am very happy to be a role model for upcoming generation of women, and I hope we will see more women in the future making films.

prompt:
How well does the following response respond to the prompt? ..... Prompt=  

After reading Lalor’s Chapter 8 as well as Goode’s explanation of curriculum evaluation necessity and models, explain what your school does to evaluate curriculum. Does your school utilize one of the models mentioned in Goode’s article?  (Tyler, Haba, Stake, Chronbach, CIPP) If not,how specifically does your school evaluate curriculum?  Is it effective?  Why or why not? 

Response=  

In Thornton Township district 205 the curriculum evaluation is mostly driven by the teachers and evaluated yearly over the course of the summer with “summer content institutes” in teams that consist of content area teachers and administrators. The team works together to review the textbook resource and teacher created resources to ensure alignment to content goals and Common Core standards. The method of curriculum evaluation used by Thornton district 205 mostly resembles the “Tabba Model” (Goode, 2019).   

I would say that this method is effective in theory however in practice not so much. Many teachers do not use the resources the teams create over the summers except the teachers on the team. There needs to be consistent use of the materials and unit plans to create a true gauge of effectiveness. To improve upon this, we would need curriculum teams consistently using the common unit structures and assessments and tracking of the data. With consistent data analysis, the curriculum's effectiveness can be determined and the decisions informed.  

 

 

Works Cited 

Goode, Kristen.  Curriculum Evaluation: Process and Models.  Study.com.  Retrieved October 12, 2019.

prompt: Write me a 2000 word essay on a water safety engineering project.
answer: The purpose of this project was to assess the risk of a flood occurring at Shelly Beach, Sydney, Australia. To do so, a flood modelling study was performed using the software package, Flood Modeller Pro. A rainfall-runoff model was first set up for the catchment area, using data from the local water authority, Sydney Water. Based on this model, a flood map was produced. The flood map was then used to set up a two-dimensional numerical model, which was used to simulate the peak discharge that could be expected during a flood event. The results showed that a flood event with a 1-in-100 year chance of occurrence could cause flooding in the area.

prompt: Expand on the relation between inconsistency and ideological thinking
answer: Inconsistency in ideology can occur for multiple reasons. First, a person may adopt an ideology early in life and fail to develop new ideas as they mature, thus remaining unchanged. Second, a person can hold an ideology for emotional reasons, such as in order to belong to a social group, rather than for rational reasons. Finally, a person can hold an ideology because the ideology they hold is in line with their self-interest, such as holding racist ideas when those ideas provide the person with a sense of social status.

prompt: Why do people give Reddit Gold to admins?
answer:
Admins on Reddit perform many tasks that are very time consuming and often thankless. They help moderate the subreddits, enforce the rules, and generally make sure things run smoothly. Because of this, they are often thanked with upvotes and gifts. 

Reddit Gold is a premium service that allows users to purchase a subscription that gives them additional features and abilities. It is the virtual currency used on the site and can be used to either purchase premium subscriptions or to gift to other users. 

Because admins do so much for the site and the community, many users will periodically give them Reddit Gold as a thank you for their hard work.

prompt: Create an Annotated Bibliography, in APA citation style, with six entries describing a different social media technology in each of the following six categories: blogs, social networking sites, virtual social worlds, virtual game worlds, collaborative projects, content communities.
answer: 1. Blogs: Blogs are web sites that are designed to be frequently updated, most often with written content. They are frequently written in an informal or conversational style. 2. Social Networking Sites: Social networking sites are web sites that are designed to help people connect with friends and others who share similar interests. Examples of popular social networking sites are Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn. 3. Virtual Social Worlds: Virtual social worlds are computer-based simulations of social environments that are designed to be inhabited by many users at the same time. Examples of popular virtual social worlds are Second Life and Blue Mars. 4. Virtual Game Worlds: Virtual game worlds are computer-based simulations of games that can be played by many people simultaneously. Examples of popular virtual game worlds are World of Warcraft and Eve Online. 5. Collaborative Projects: Collaborative projects are web sites that are designed to enable people to work together on a common purpose. Examples of popular collaborative projects are Wikipedia and Open Street Map. 6. Content Communities: Content communities are web sites that are designed to bring people together who are interested in a particular topic. Examples of popular content communities are Reddit and Digg.

prompt: You are a script-writer. Write a script for the opening scene of a Miami-based dark comedy show which depicts a typical miami beach club called Beefy's Beach Club run buy a british man known by the Alias Beefy, and the pool bar staff are JdeG and a blonde british woman with the Alias SophieSnazz
answer:
Beefy's Beach Club, Miami

It's 4pm on a Friday, and the sun is shining. The pool bar is packed, and the music is blasting. The pool is full of bikini clad women and men with their shirts off, all drinking cocktails and generally having a good time. Beefy, the owner of the club, comes out onto the pool deck to check on things. He is a tall, muscular man with a full head of hair. He is wearing a white T-shirt and boardshorts, and he has a full beard. He gives JdeG and SophieSnazz some instructions, and then walks back into the clubhouse.

JdeG is about to go back in the clubhouse himself, but SophieSnazz gives him a hug and kisses him on the cheek. JdeG smiles and says "Don't get too touchy-feely with me, sweetheart. I'm going in there to have a few drinks with Beefy." SophieSnazz rolls her eyes and says "Oh, you're such a player." as she walks away. JdeG chuckles to himself as he walks back into the clubhouse.

prompt:
6Rephrase this article into a third person and conversational and very unique 2000 words article include a headings about  Based on our investigation so far, Reddit user passwords and accounts are safe, but on Sunday night (pacific time), Reddit systems were hacked as a result of a sophisticated and highly-targeted phishing attack. They gained access to some internal documents, code, and some internal business systems.

What Happened?
On late (PST) February 5, 2023, we became aware of a sophisticated phishing campaign that targeted Reddit employees. As in most phishing campaigns, the attacker sent out plausible-sounding prompts pointing employees to a website that cloned the behavior of our intranet gateway, in an attempt to steal credentials and second-factor tokens.

After successfully obtaining a single employee’s credentials, the attacker gained access to some internal docs, code, as well as some internal dashboards and business systems. We show no indications of breach of our primary production systems (the parts of our stack that run Reddit and store the majority of our data).

Exposure included limited contact information for (currently hundreds of) company contacts and employees (current and former), as well as limited advertiser information. Based on several days of initial investigation by security, engineering, and data science (and friends!), we have no evidence to suggest that any of your non-public data has been accessed, or that Reddit’s information has been published or distributed online.

How Did We Respond?
Soon after being phished, the affected employee self-reported, and the Security team responded quickly, removing the infiltrator’s access and commencing an internal investigation. Similar phishing attacks have been recently reported. We’re continuing to investigate and monitor the situation closely and working with our employees to fortify our security skills. As we all know, the human is often the weakest part of the security chain.

Our goal is to fully understand and prevent future incidents of this nature, and we will use this post to provide any additional updates as we learn and can share more. So far, it also appears that many of the lessons we learned five years ago have continued to be useful.

User Account Protection
Since we’re talking about security and safety, this is a good time to remind you how to protect your Reddit account. The most important (and simple) measure you can take is to set up 2FA (two-factor authentication) which adds an extra layer of security when you access your Reddit account. Learn how to enable 2FA in Reddit Help. And if you want to take it a step further, it’s always a good idea to update your password every couple of months – just make sure it’s strong and unique for greater protection.

Also: use a password manager! Besides providing great complicated passwords, they provide an extra layer of security by warning you before you use your password on a phishing site… because the domains won’t match!

…AMA!
The team and I will stick around for the next few hours to try to answer questions. Since our investigation is still ongoing and this is about our security practices, we can’t necessarily answer everything in great detail, but we’ll do our best to live up to Default Open here.
answer: Reddit users are safe. We've identified the attacker account and banned it. We're not currently seeing evidence of any data breach. We're still investigating the extent of the attack and the impact it had on our systems.

Microsoft has confirmed it is investing billions of dollars into ChatGPT maker OpenAI, which could benefit Windows.

Microsoft is working on ‘Windows 12’, according to sources familiar with the company’s internal plans. While Windows 11 remains a work in progress, a group of engineers are already working on the next big release (an all-new version of Windows – possibly called Windows 12?).
Microsoft is significantly changing with Windows 12, bringing in several AI-powered features. We don’t know how exactly the company plans to use AI in Windows. Still, you can expect OpenAI-powered recommendations or alerts within apps like Mail & Calendar, Clock, Microsoft Photos, and more.

Of course, Microsoft doesn’t want to wait for Windows 12 to deliver the first round of AI features, so some “AI” features could land in Windows 11 in the coming months.

This includes smarter camera and microphone features in Windows. For example, Microsoft uses AI to automatically blur the background, correct the brightness, eye, and much more. Likewise, Windows could also filter the background noise and increase the clarity of your primary voice.

Microsoft teased Windows 12 at CES 2023
During the AMD keynote at CES 2023, Microsoft’s Panos Panay, chief product officer, discussed the future of Windows and AI. At CES 2023, Panos suggested that Windows will be betting big on AI with several features, including vastly improved voice and video capabilities to make you look better in video calls.

“AI is going to reinvent how you do everything on Windows, quite literally,” Panos Panay told the audience without getting into much detail about how AI will empower Windows users.

Microsoft needs a dedicated AI engine to improve the tech in the OS. Thankfully, AMD is working on a new range of CPUs with AI technology which addresses Microsoft’s concerns.

The chipmaker doesn’t plan to ship PCs with a separate AI engine tied to the GPU. Instead, its CPU will have the necessary AI integration. AMD’s AI-powered CPUs could help Microsoft deliver AI features and keep performance high.

Windows 12 AI camera feature
Portrait Blur-like feature may use advanced AI
Panos explained that these models, like language models, cogen models, and image models, “are so powerful, so delightful, so useful, and personal, but they also very compute intensive”.

“It’s going to require an operating system that blurs the line between the cloud and edge, and that’s what we’re doing right now. It takes the right silicon in the right place to deliver the best experience,” he added.

Major versions of Windows to ship every three years
Microsoft has internally made significant changes to the Windows roadmap, and Windows will have a three-year release cycle. In other words, significant versions of Windows will ship every three years.

Windows 11 was released in 2021, which means a major version of Windows should arrive sometime in 2024. In theory, this appears to be the case, but that doesn’t necessarily mean the major 2024 update will be called Windows 12. Unfortunately, the release date of Windows 12 remains a mystery.

After 2024, another big version will release in 2027, and the cycle will repeat (unless Microsoft changes the roadmap).

We should begin to see AI-related improvements in Windows 11 this year as AMD’s AI PCs come to market, and then we can see “significant” changes with Windows 12.

Microsoft has gone all in on artificial intelligence (AI), pouring $10 billion in the OpenAI startup — and that’s just the opening gambit. Expect many more billions to follow.

There’s good reason for that investment. AI will reap many billions in revenue for the company, particularly its cloud business. Microsoft already has released a public preview of its cloud-based Azure OpenAI service which will allow businesses to use AI without having to build infrastructure. Yesterday it unveiled plans to add AI to Bing in a bid to take market share from Google. And it will probably be built into the guts of Office to improve user productivity.

But keep in mind we’re now at the peak of AI hype, that point in a new technology’s life cycle when there are sky-high predictions but few clear benefits and even less revenue. It’s when tech companies promise the moon and the stars without having to back it up with down-to-earth realities.


And so, Microsoft isn’t content to just make predictions how AI will transform the cloud, Internet search or productivity tools. It’s also boasting about how AI will change Windows, notably the work-in-progress Windows 12.


Just consider what Microsoft Chief Product Officer Panos Panay, in charge of Windows and its hardware,  said at the CES conference in early January: “Artificial Intelligence is going to reinvent how you do everything on Windows, quite literally.

“Like these large generative models, think language models, code gen models, image models; these models are so powerful, so delightful, so useful, personal…, It's gonna need an operating system that blurs the line between cloud and edge, and that's what we are doing right now.”

(Bonus points for anyone who can decipher Panay’s word salad and explain how AI models can possibly be called “delightful.”)

What might all this AI magic do on Windows 12? Panay offered only a single example: Zoom meetings would be better because AI will provide better Zoom backgrounds, and make it appear that your eyes are looking directly at the camera, even when they’re wandering off to the side.

Ten billion dollars for prettier Zoom meetings? Be still my beating heart!

It’s likely Microsoft is cooking up things more impressive than that in its labs. But those things might not make it into Windows. To understand why, let’s first look at how AI might work in Windows 12.

Windows AI chips
Microsoft hasn’t detailed exactly how AI will integrate into Windows 12, but we're getting hints of a potential roadmap.  Chipmakers right now are making and releasing PC chips that include dedicated hardware devoted to AI. AMD has released the first ones, its Ryzen 7040 series. In fact, Panay delivered his AI promises at CES during an AMD press conference announcing the chips.

Parts of Windows already use AI, where it’s involved in everything from system management to search, speech recognition, grammar correction, and even noise suppression and camera image processing. Some of that AI processing is typically farmed out to the cloud. Some can be done on a PC’s graphics chip or its main CPU. With onboard AI-specific hardware, though, the processing could be done right on the PC.

Theoretically, that should lead to benefits, although exactly what those benefits might be aren’t clear. Analysts point to things like better searching and improved image processing. Stephen Kleynhans, a vice president of research at Gartner had this to say: “Who knows, maybe Cortana will make a comeback!” To which I say: Be careful what you wish for.

What can we expect from AI in Windows?
Panay says the new chips with AI processors in them, such as those from AMD, will pave the way for an AI-powered Windows 12. That sounds fine in theory. But in practice, it’s extremely problematic because Windows has to work on an astonishingly wide variety of chips and hardware.

That’s one of Windows’ biggest strengths and one of its greatest weaknesses. It allows manufacturers to build ultra-cheap, barebone laptops and desktops, top-of-the-line power laptops and desktops, and mid-range laptops and desktops, so consumers get the widest range of choices at a variety of prices.

But it’s a weakness because getting Windows to work on so many different kinds of computers, including many flavors of AI processors and many PCs without AI processors, will greatly limit how AI can be integrated into Windows and the benefits users might actually see.

For Windows 12 to run on all that disparate hardware, Microsoft can take one of two approaches. One is to design Windows 12 for the lowest-common denominator, which would mean for computers that don’t have powerful AI processors on board. That, in turn, would mean Microsoft can’t reinvent AI as Panay promised.

The other approach is to design different versions of Windows 12 for different pieces of hardware. Those with powerful AI processors would get the AI-powered version, those with no AI processors or low-powered ones would get a less feature-rich version.

Microsoft tried this second approach once before, with Windows Vista, and it was an unmitigated disaster, leading to angry, confused consumers, lawsuits against the company, and a top Microsoft exec admitting, “We really botched this.”

Back then, Microsoft released two versions of Vista, one that ran the full operating system on fully powered PCs, and another, for less-powerful PCs Microsoft called “Windows Vista Capable PCs,” that lacked many of the operating system’s best capabilities.

How bad was the stripped-down Windows version on Vista Capable PCs? Mike Nash, a corporate vice president for Windows product management, wrote in an email message, "I PERSONALLY got burnt.... I now have a $2,100 e-mail machine." An unnamed Microsoft employee wrote in an email, "Even a piece of junk will qualify" to be called Windows Vista Capable. And Jim Allchin, who was co-president of Microsoft's Platforms and Services Division, wrote in an email, "We really botched this.... You guys have to do a better job with our customers."

I’m betting that Microsoft learned from that disaster and won’t design multiple versions of Windows for different kinds of PCs. Which would mean designing for the lowest-common denominator and forgoing a fully AI-powered version of Windows.

prompt:
Mill vs Gartner
This case is about a dispute over the right to dig clay on a piece of land. The plaintiffs argued that the defendant, Allen, had only a verbal agreement, or a "parol license," to enter the land and take clay. The defendant claimed that he had an actual leasehold interest in the land, which entitled him to dig clay. The court found that the defendant's defense was sufficient, as it constituted a lease of the land for the purpose of taking clay. The court also found that the defendant's offer of testimony was admissible, and that the testimony was sufficient to submit to the jury. The court concluded that the trial judge had properly ruled on the case and that the judgment should be affirmed.

Smith vs Mill Company
The case is about the interpretation of a clause in a lease agreement between the lessors and lessees regarding the payment of taxes on coal in the ground. The clause in question stated that the lessors must pay all taxes imposed on the coal in the ground. The court held that the meaning of the clause was clear and plain, and that it was an absolute obligation on the part of the lessors to pay the taxes. The court also considered the effect of deeds of conveyance made after the lease agreement and concluded that they did not change the rights of the parties under the lease agreement. The court further held that the lessees still had the exclusive privilege to take the coal and were subject to the same duties as under the lease agreement, and the lessors still held all the beneficial interests that they held under the lease agreement. The court concluded that the positive agreement of the lessors to pay the taxes was not dependent on any technical aspect of their interest in the coal and was absolute, peremptory, and without condition.

Gartner vs Baker
The case of "Opinion, Min Justice Mitchell" was an ejectment lawsuit brought by plaintiffs against defendants who claimed to hold possession of the plaintiffs' land as lessees. The case revolved around a lease agreement made in 1864 between the plaintiffs (who were minors at the time and represented by their guardians) and the defendants, who were lessees of the land. The lease was made with the approval of a special act of assembly. The defendants claimed that the title was res adjudicata and the judge at the trial agreed, except for the continuance of the lease beyond twenty years, which he held to still be in force as a matter of law. The remaining specifications of error raised four questions, including the constitutionality of the act of assembly, the execution of the lease in accordance with the act, the validity of the lease, and whether it had expired by its own terms. These questions were resolved in favor of the defendants and the decree was affirmed by the court in a brief per curiam opinion, referring to the absence of fraud.

Which of these cases are a good fit for "Find me cases where the dispute involved involve mine leases."? Include a summary for each.
answer: The cases of "Mill vs Gartner", "Smith vs Mill Company", and "Gartner vs Baker" are all good fits for "Find me cases where the dispute involved mine leases."

prompt: How can anti-deressants make people think or act suicidally? Suicidal thoughts or actions' are a side effect of every single anti-depressant I've seen. Is the medicine controlling your mind or something?
answer:
Antidepressants work by altering the levels of neurotransmitters in the brain. Neurotransmitters are chemicals which carry signals from one nerve cell to another. The levels of some of these neurotransmitters are thought to be out of balance in people suffering from depression. Anti-depressants work by either inhibiting or stimulating the re-uptake of these neurotransmitters back into the nerve cells. This in turn increases the levels of these neurotransmitters in the brain. This is the mechanism by which these drugs work.

There are many kinds of anti-depressants and they all work in slightly different ways. This is the reason why it is important to consult a doctor before starting any anti-depressant. It is also important to note that anti-depressants take time to start working. It can take up to 4-6 weeks before you start feeling any better. You need to give the medication time to work. If you do not notice any improvement in your symptoms within 2-3 weeks, you need to consult your doctor. It is also important to note that you need to continue taking the medication for 6 months to a year even after you start feeling better. Stopping the medication suddenly can result in your symptoms returning.

It is important to note that suicidal thoughts are a common side effect of anti-depressants. This means that if you are on an anti-depressant, you are more likely to have suicidal thoughts than a person who is not on any medication. This is why it is very important that you consult your doctor before starting any anti-depressant. It is also important to monitor yourself closely for any changes in your mood or any other physical symptoms while on an anti-depressant. If you notice any changes in your mood or any other physical symptoms while on an anti-depressant, you need to consult your doctor as soon as possible.

prompt: Draft a ministerial speech outlining the top five benefits that innovation brings to the Australian economy
answer:
Innovation is a driver of economic growth, and the Australian economy has been able to maintain strong growth over the last three decades, even through global financial crises. Below are the top five benefits that innovation brings to the Australian economy:

1. Innovation is a driver of economic growth. New and improved products, processes and services lead to increased productivity and higher incomes for businesses and workers.
2. Innovation creates new industries and expands existing industries. Businesses and workers are able to take advantage of new opportunities that arise as a result of innovation.
3. Innovation allows for the creation of new jobs. New and improved products, processes and services require additional workers to be able to be produced and delivered.
4. Innovation makes the economy more resilient. New and improved products, processes and services allow businesses and workers to better adapt to changes in the external environment.
5. Innovation improves the lives of Australian people. New and improved products, processes and services allow businesses and workers to better serve the needs of the Australian people.

Anakin Skywalker is visiting the Jedi archives on Coruscant, when he encounters an old Master who is reading a very old book. The Master seems to be studying the book very closely, so Anakin asks if he can be of any help. The Master responds that he would appreciate if Anakin could look up a particular passage for him.

Anakin goes to the reference section of the archives and begins to search for the passage. As he is looking, he notices that the Master seems to be frowning and muttering to himself as he studies his book. Anakin asks the Master if he needs any help, and the Master responds that he is quite capable of finding what he is looking for on his own. He then tells Anakin that he was just making a small adjustment to his calculations, and that he should continue looking.

Anakin completes his search and returns to the Master, who is still frowning at his book. Anakin asks the Master if he could finally read the passage to him, and the Master responds that he is still making a few final adjustments to his calculations. He then tells Anakin that he will read the passage to him when he is finished, and that he should return in a few moments.

Anakin returns to the reference section and sits down at his reading pod. He begins to meditate, hoping to calm his mind and focus on the task at hand. He has just begun to clear his thoughts when he hears the Master calling to him from across the archives. The Master tells Anakin that he is ready to read the passage, and that Anakin should come to him immediately.

Anakin leaves his meditation and rushes to the Master, who is nowhere to be found. All of a sudden, Anakin notices that he is not on Coruscant at all, but rather on the Jedi Temple on Tython. The Master is standing in front of him, and he is holding Anakin's lightsaber in his hand. He then hands Anakin the lightsaber and asks him to do him a very small favor. He tells Anakin that he is about to make a small adjustment to his calculations, and that he should return in a few moments.

prompt: How does money go from my pocket, through the stock market, and to support the business I've bought stock from?
answer: Let's look at an example using Apple as the company you've invested in.  You buy an Apple stock at $100 per share.  You may pay $102 for the share, or you may pay $99, depending on how the market is moving that day.  The important thing to understand is that you now own the stock, and you have a claim to $100 worth of that company.  If the price of Apple stock rises to $105, you now have an additional $5 per share, for a total of $105.  You can sell this share to someone else for $105, and you've made a 5% return on your investment.  If the share price drops to $95, you now own 95 shares of the company worth $100 each, and you've lost 5% of your investment.

prompt: Explain me the Finite Elemente Method
answer: The finite element method (FEM) is a computational method for solving boundary value problems in engineering analysis. It uses a finite element to approximate an unknown function defined on a domain. Since the domain is often geometrically complex, the finite element can be formulated as an element of a function space. The solution to the boundary value problem is obtained by finding the values of the function at the elements. The elements are connected together with continuous piecewise linear elements and satisfy appropriate boundary conditions.

prompt: Introduce the ”financial markets and institutions“ by Frederic S. Mishkin
answer:
Financial markets and institutions are the means by which people and businesses borrow and lend money. The financial markets and their associated institutions include money markets, credit markets, and capital markets. Financial markets are places where people and institutions can buy and sell financial assets. Financial assets include not only money, but also bonds, stocks, and derivatives. 

Financial markets and their associated institutions are typically classified into one of four main types: money markets, capital markets, credit markets, and derivatives markets. In turn, these markets are made up of many sub-markets, which can be categorized by the type of asset or liability, the maturity, the quality, or some other characteristic.

prompt: Act like a first-year college student and write a 1000-1250 word two-topic essay by using at least three points of analysis. Topic 1 is my experiences living in and observations of  Flagstaff, Arizona.   Topic 2 is my experiences living in and observations of  Kaneohe, Hawaii. Use quotes from two sources in the essay. Use descriptive language.  Include personal anecdotes.  These sources will be listed in a Works Cited at the end of the essay. Use a four in-text citations in MLA style in the body of the essay.
answer:
The first time I visited Flagstaff, Arizona it was January of 2013. I was in the middle of a 10-month solo road trip across the country. I had spent the previous day in the Grand Canyon and was on my way to Las Vegas. I got off the freeway at a rest stop that had a view of the San Francisco Peaks. I grabbed my backpack and headed into the woods to explore. It was a clear night and the temperature had dropped to about 20 degrees Fahrenheit. I was wearing only a t-shirt so I quickly made my way back to the car. I saw a sign that said "Flagstaff" and decided to stay the night. I drove into town and was shocked at how cold it was. I had never been to a place that cold before. It was so cold I couldn't breathe if I walked more than a few steps. I drove to the nearest gas station and bought a bag of chips. I didn't know where I would sleep, but I knew I would be safe in my car. I drove to the lowest point in town which was a few blocks from the train tracks. I parked the car, and set-up camp. I had a sleeping bag and a small heater. It was so cold I could see my breath as I walked back to the car. I set the heater to the highest setting and crawled into my sleeping bag. I had on all of my clothes and a couple of blankets. I was so cold I couldn't sleep. I kept waking up to make sure I hadn't frozen to death. I eventually fell asleep and woke up to the sound of snow falling. I bundled up and walked to a nearby convenience store to get a coffee. The weather had warmed up a little and the snow had stopped. It was the most beautiful scene I had ever seen. I walked back to my car and called my mom to tell her I was still alive. I spent the next few days exploring Flagstaff. I hiked to the highest point in Arizona and saw the San Francisco Peaks. I drove to the Grand Canyon and hiked down to the Colorado River. I loved Flagstaff and decided to come back and spend a few months there.

I moved back to Flagstaff in May of 2013. This time I bought a car and had a place to live. The first month I was there someone stole my vehicle and I had to walk home. I decided I was not going to let that happen again so I got a bike. I rode my bike everywhere. I would ride to the coffee shop and pick up a bagel. I would ride to the grocery store and pick-up a sandwich. I would ride to the library and check out a book. I would ride to the park and read a book. I loved living in Flagstaff. The locals were friendly and the weather was great. I would spend the summer hiking and the winter skiing. It was the perfect place to live.

After spending a year in Flagstaff I decided I wanted to live by the ocean. I decided to visit Hawaii and see if I liked it. I flew to Honolulu and spent a few days in Waikiki Beach. I loved it! I decided to move there. I flew to Oahu and found an apartment on the Ewa Plain. I spent the next 8 months living in Hawaii. I hiked Diamond Head, snorkeled at Hanauma Bay, and climbed to the top of the Dole Plantation. I loved living in Hawaii. I could see the ocean from my apartment. I would walk to the beach and watch the sunset. I would go for a run and watch the surfers catch waves. It was the perfect place to live.

prompt: what is the recommended pattern for creating games in godot
answer:
In godot, the recommended way to create a game is to use the scene system. Every scene has its own state (for example, the main character could be idle or walking) and its own assets (for example, a background image and a character animation). Scenes can be composed into a hierarchy (for example, a main menu scene and a game scene) and the game can be played by switching between these scenes. Changes to the scene (for example, the character could start walking) are triggered by events (for example, a user clicking on a button).

The scene system is very flexible and allows you to easily build complex games with a small number of scenes. It is also easy to learn and use, which makes godot a good choice for creating small games.

prompt:
question about Computer architecture and organization 
for 6 marks
what in general terms is the distinction between computer organization and computer architecture ?
give answer in full sentence points if possible
answer: The terms computer organization and computer architecture are used interchangeably in the popular literature to refer to the way computers are built from basic hardware components. In technical literature, the terms are used in a more formal and precise manner to refer to two distinct concepts. Computer organization is the way in which hardware components are connected to work as a system, and computer architecture is the way in which those components are (or should be) organized to perform a particular computing task.

prompt:
Simplify "Most of the basic functions of current virtualization software are inherited from this early VM OS. The virtualization software is now represented with the term hypervisor. Hardware virtualization is used to share the resources of the cloud providers effectively with the customers by generating an illusion of dedicated computing, storage, and networking on a computing infrastructure.

The concept of virtualization is physically implemented using the hypervisor modules, and the operation and processing of hypervisors are materialized by the OSS. In other words, hypervisor modules are installed on top of OSS, which act as an interface between hardware units and hypervisor packages."
answer:
Virtualization is the creation of a software-based (or hardware-based) computer environment that is Logically isolated from the underlying computer hardware. It provides the ability to run multiple Operating Systems (OS) on a single computer.

The main benefits of a virtualized environment include:

1. Eliminates the need to purchase, maintain, and update multiple physical computers
2. Reduces energy consumption by ensuring that only the hardware resources needed by a particular virtual machine are used
3. Allows a server to be shared by multiple virtual machines
4. Easier to backup and protect the virtualized environment

prompt: i assume you are familiar with the Drake equation. Can you give estimates and error margins for each of its parameters, then calculate the result including error bounds.
answer:
The Drake equation is a simplified way to think about the conditions that are needed for intelligent life to form. The equation has 8 terms, each of which is a fraction. The factors in the first two terms are well known and have been estimated by many astronomers. The values for these factors are:

N = the number of stars in the Milky Way galaxy
R* = the average distance of stars from the galactic center
fp = the fraction of stars that have planets
ne = the number of Earth-like planets per star
fl = the fraction of Earth-like planets that develop life
fi = the fraction of life bearing planets that evolve intelligence
L = the length of time such intelligence can transmit signals into space
We assume for the sake of discussion that the answer to this equation is 1. This means that there is exactly one technologically advanced civilization in the Milky Way galaxy. The total error in this answer is at least a factor of 10, which is the largest error in any of these terms. The largest contributor to the error is the factor fp which is very poorly known. Estimates range from 1 in 10 to 1 in 100. Since we are assuming that the answer to the Drake equation is 1, the largest contribution to the error is fp.

Can a single pane window be more efficient than a double pane window? If yes, what is needed for this? Support your answer with appropriate calculations.
answer: In a cold climate, double pane windows are more energy efficient than single pane windows, because the second pane of glass helps prevent the heat from escaping. In a hot climate, triple pane windows are more energy efficient than double pane windows, because the additional pane of glass helps prevent the heat from entering. Since heat always flows from a warmer place to a cooler place, the outer pane of glass should be made of a material with a low thermal conductivity (such as air) and the middle pane should be made of a material with a high thermal conductivity (such as glass).

prompt: explain TypeScript and Duck Typing
answer:
TypeScript is a typed superset of JavaScript. It has great tooling support and allows you to write code that is type safe.
Duck Typing is a feature of dynamic languages that allows you to use an object without having to know its type at runtime. This works based on the fact that all objects respond to all of the methods that are implemented on their base type. So you can call a method on an object that has not been defined in that object's type definition. This is very useful when working with frameworks or libraries that you don't have the source code for and you are not allowed to change.

prompt:
Write up insights from the book Upstream by Dan Heath and the book’s application to a team of Social Workers at Visalia Unified School District that have the following job description:
Under the direction of an assigned supervisor, the School Social Worker will provide school-based mental health services at school sites. The School Social Worker will assess and define problems children may be experiencing with school attendance and performance, family interactions, social problems and school-community relations which interfere with the student’s ability and potential to obtain a satisfactory education; consult and assist parents, teachers and others concerned with the child and his family in planning appropriate strategies for the problem and to assure services are provided according to planned strategy. 
Typical Duties:
1.	Establish with the child and the family a milieu where personal, interpersonal and intrafamilial concerns may be openly shared and discussed.
2.	Consult and collaborate with school personnel to promote a school environment responsive to the needs of children.
3.	Serve as a catalyst to generate, enhance and facilitate the problem-solving process as it affects individuals, groups, institutions and systems.
4.	Serve as an intercessor for students and their family in dealing with community agencies and institutions and with the school system; serve as an intercessor for the school system in dealing with community agencies and institutions.
5.	Conduct mental health and ongoing individual therapy for students
6.	Collect, gather, sort and analyze data about students, parents, and the communities served by the District.
7.	Supervise on-going activities of social work interns from university programs.
8.	Participate in special programs such as the Foster Youth Program as assigned.
9.	Perform related duties as assigned.
Personal Characteristics: 
Should possess the personal characteristics generally recognized as essential for good public employees including integrity, initiative, emotional maturity, dependability, courtesy, good judgment and ability to work cooperatively with others. 
Position Qualifications: 
Knowledge of:   
Effective personal and academic counseling techniques and procedures; counseling theory, ethics and associated legal confidentiality requirements; laws regarding minors and child abuse reporting; applicable sections of the State Education Code and other applicable laws, rules and regulations related to assigned activities; normal and abnormal child behavior and development; behavior modification techniques and strategies; student assistance programs; community referral resources; diverse academic, socioeconomic, cultural, disability, and ethnic backgrounds of District students; interpersonal skills using tact, patience and courtesy; correct English usage, grammar, spelling, punctuation and vocabulary; record-keeping techniques.
Ability and Skills to: 
Provide counseling and guidance services to students; engage a broad network of partners committed to improving the future of all members of the community; make referrals to other community resources, support groups and social service agencies as appropriate; plan, prepare and conduct individual and group counseling sessions; read, interpret, apply and explain rules, regulations, policies and procedures; maintain current knowledge of program rules, regulations, requirements and restrictions; manipulate and configure data to 
form statistical analysis; set limits and personal boundaries for students; assist with curriculum development; complete work with many interruptions; analyze situations accurately and adopt an effective course of action; work independently with little direction; meet schedules and time lines; work confidentially with discretion; maintain records and prepare various reports, including confidential materials; establish and maintain cooperative and effective working relationships with others; maintain consistent, punctual and regular attendance; sit or stand for extended periods of time; walk around the campus; lift heavy objects weighing up to 50 pounds; exchange information with others; monitor student behavior. 
Certificate/License/Insurance Requirement:   
Valid California Driver’s License and proof of vehicle insurance required. Licensed as Clinical Social Worker or Associate Clinical Social Worker by the California Board of Behavioral Sciences is preferred. 
Experience:   
One year of experience working with “at-risk” students in an educational or social services setting is desired.   
Education:   
Master of Social Work Degree or PPS credential with master’s degree in a related field required.
answer: The Visalia Unified School District (VUSD) School Social Worker team is a unique group of professionals who are highly trained to work with students and families in a school setting. The VUSD School Social Worker team provides comprehensive mental health services to students, families, and staff to support student success. This includes providing individual, group, and family therapy services, consultation and crisis intervention, and coordination of community resources as needed. School Social Workers are an integral part of the VUSD team and have strong relationships with teachers, administrators, and other community service providers. The VUSD School Social Worker team is committed to being a part of the solution in building strong and resilient communities.

prompt: What are the wavelengths of light emitted by metals depending on their temperature?

prompt: Explain sarcoidosis to me like I’m a five year old
answer: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that affects the lungs, skin, and sometimes other organs.  It can cause tiny clumps of cells called granulomas to form in different tissues of the body.  These clumps are what cause the inflammation.  It is not clear what causes these cells to clump together.  Some researchers think it is an immune system response to an infection the body can’t get rid of.  Others think it is caused by a problem with the body’s ability to regulate the immune system.  No one is really sure.  Doctors often use the word “idiopathic” to describe a disease they don’t know what caused it.  In sarcoidosis, the immune system cells that are supposed to protect the body from infections and other invaders instead end up attacking the body.  This causes inflammation and the clumping of cells into granulomas.  This inflammation can cause a lot of damage to the tissue that these cells are sitting in.  The most common tissue to be affected is the lungs.  This is why symptoms often start with a cough.  Some people only have a few granulomas but others can have a lot.  These granulomas can get too big and cause the tissue they are in to get squeezed.  If the lungs are the most commonly affected tissue, this can lead to shortness of breath and trouble breathing.  If the skin is affected, it can lead to red and scaly patches that can be itchy.  If the eyes are affected, it can lead to swelling and vision problems.  If the heart is affected, it can lead to chest pain and an irregular heartbeat.  There is no cure for sarcoidosis but treatment can help control the symptoms.  Doctors treat it with medications that can help reduce inflammation and slow the growth of the granulomas.  Some people need strong medications to control it but for others, milder medications can work just fine.  Some people also need to take medications to treat any lung problems or heart problems that develop as a result of the disease.  There is also a small chance that sarcoidosis can come back after treatment is stopped so it is important to work closely with your doctor to monitor your health and make sure treatment is working.

prompt: write a chronology of important events related to ESG in 2022
answer:
ESG 2022
- 10 February: Goldman Sachs announces the launch of a new index, the Global ESG 100 Index, which will track the performance of 100 of the world's largest publicly listed companies based on their environmental, social and governance (ESG) practices. 
- 10 February: BlackRock announces that it will re-launch its flagship ESG fund, the $17.3bn BlackRock ESG Fund, as a multi-sector fund that will include up to 100 holdings. 
- 22 February: The Bank of England announces that it will no longer invest in or hold shares in fossil fuel companies. 
- 23 February: The World Economic Forum releases its 2022 Global Risk Report, which ranks climate change as the world's top long-term threat.

prompt: Is it rational to believe things for which there is no objective evidence?
answer: It is rational to believe things for which there is no objective evidence, as long as you are willing to revise your beliefs if new evidence becomes available.  Take the example of a person born and raised in the United States who has never been to Canada.  It is perfectly rational for this person to believe that Canada is part of the United States based on their limited experience.  If and when this person actually visits Canada, they will learn that Canada is in fact a separate country.  This person's belief that Canada is part of the United States was not irrational, but it was incorrect.  It is important to be able to distinguish between incorrect and irrational beliefs.

prompt:
A man has a rather old car being worth $2000.
He saw a secondhand car being worth $8000. He wants to keep his old car until he can buy the secondhand one.
He thinks he can save $1000 each month but the prices of his old
car and of the new one decrease of 1.5 percent per month.
Furthermore this percent of loss increases of `0.5` percent
Our man finds it difficult to make all these calculations.
Can you help him?
How many months will it take him to save up enough money to buy the car he wants,
and how much money will he have left over?
answer: In order to save up $1000 each month our man will need to save for 6 months. During this time his old car and the new car will loose their value by 9 months * 0.5 percent = 4.5 percent. Therefore he will have $1000 * 1.045 = $1045 after 6 months. This will be enough money to buy the new car.

prompt: 7 / 7Write a detailed patent writing for an innovative and novel way of issuing community tax certificates and other relevant permits and clearances as a digital certificates,  that is non-obvious using verifiable credentials, digital wallet on a blockchain as payment provision, and machine learning. Include claims on detailed processes involved, system architecture and algorithms
answer:
Community tax certificates are issued to property owners by local authorities, such as municipalities, who collect property taxes as revenues. Local authorities currently issue paper certificates to property owners, which are stored in a physical file cabinet. This method of issuing certificates has several drawbacks, including inefficient storage, delayed distribution, and easy falsification. In addition, property owners must physically visit the local authorities to update their personal information, such as name, address, or property value. 

In this patent, we present a novel and non-obvious approach to issuing community tax certificates which utilizes blockchain technology. We leverage the immutability of blockchain to maintain a permanent and traceable record of all transactions. We also leverage the data sharing features of blockchain to allow local authorities to securely share information with each other, which reduces duplicate data entry and further reduces the likelihood of errors. Furthermore, we use a digital wallet to store certificates on a user’s mobile phone, which enables the certificates to be easily updated and verified by property owners. We also use a digital wallet to store the payment, which allows property owners to conveniently pay for their community taxes using cryptocurrency. Finally, we use machine learning to ensure that all necessary information for community taxes has been collected and that the taxes have been calculated correctly.

prompt:
Rewrite this text in 500 words: "There’s much that divides us in Northern Ireland though one thing is guaranteed to bring us together: local phrases. Call it slang, call it colloquialisms, we all know only too well how important words are to where we’re from . . . and when it comes to the phrases that make us ‘us,’ we’ve got a lot to say.
While you don’t need advance knowledge of the words to fit in, well, it helps. How else will you know where ‘foundered’ sits on the scale of warm to freezing? Or deciding whether that new car purchase is more ‘clinker’ than ‘beezer’? Or appreciating that ‘grand’ can mean exactly that or anything but?
If the best way to get to know a nation is to understand their language, then surely tourists must be at times confused about what comes out of our mouths. Throughout the island of Ireland, we have utterly brilliant ways to verbally express ourselves.
“I think it’s really important,” says Dr Frank Ferguson, research director for English Language and Literature at Ulster University, about the vitality of slang as part of language.
“I think sometimes we’re not sure even the meaning of slang and the meaning of the vernacular and the colloquial. Especially for Northern Ireland, where language is often so divisive, we forget how a rich and varied it is. And sometimes we find other places in the world that really value the mix of their language.
“Often the things that we associate with slang are actually part of the sort of the languages that make up what we think of as English because we have this wonderful mixture of English, Scots language, and Irish, all bubbling up together and then you have the additions on that, of slang,” he continues.
“Slang as a sort of term that’s used by certain groups to denote certain things through phrases.
“We have an incredible mix and you think how small in many ways Northern Ireland is, that there are marked differences in the language that Belfast uses and the language that’s used up in Derry. There are gradation and the usage of words and phrases that we often take for granted but they’re really quite amazing things.”
“It’s a potentially massive term,” says Gail McConnell, a writer from Belfast on slang which she says transcends distinctions of high and low culture.
“One of the reasons why so many of us love [TV show] Derry Girls so much is because it was a language, phrasing and words and speech, that was so familiar, and took such a delight and pleasure in not just Northern Irish slang but Derry-specific slang, which was a joyous thing to see on a Channel 4 programme.
“But then you’ve got someone like Pulitzer Prize-winning Paul Muldoon, the current Ireland Chair of Poetry, whose poems are peppered with slang terms, through all the decades of his writing; he’s been doing that since the 1970s and 1980s to now.
“It’s a really interesting legacy of this place and the words that make us unique.”
Language has the power to unite: it brings familiarity, a sense of community and a feeling that we’re all in this together. It is our primary tool to communicate and finding those lines of unity is vital to create bonds and friendships.
“It’s one of those things that if we go on holiday and you’re walking down the street, whether it be Spain or wherever, and you hear something from home. It can be something like ‘yer ma’, or ‘yer man’ and that will convey a whole host of knowledge and sense of place that somethings don’t and can’t,” says Dr Ferguson.
“There’s something very unmistakeably ours about words and phrases that we use and there’s nothing more honest at times and nothing more radical.
“Sometimes we might get anxious that we’re using cliches, but we’re actually using things that are very unguarded in our speech.”
Think too of Line of Duty’s Ted Hastings, who may be not living in Northern Ireland but ensures his team appreciate he didn’t come up the Lagan in a bubble.
In popular culture, like Gail, Dr Ferguson also references Lisa McGee’s Derry Girls that unashamedly used phrases and terminology from this place.
“That really said something of the exceptionalism of who we are and what we say.
“Sometimes we’ve been too quick almost to laugh at ourselves for those words, because I think a lot of it is the way society tries to engineer us with an idea of what is proper language, whereas what we say communicates extremely effectively and works better than sometimes the phraseology of standard English.”
But our local phrases are not immune from what goes on here.
“I think it’s unfortunate that it’s been politicised by a face-off between the Irish language and Ulster Scots,” says Gail.
“It’s so frustrating but I think there’s definitely more that we have in common. I think people are often not that sure of the history of slang terms, what the root of it is and where it started.
“And it’s such a source of comedy; I think some of the best of Irish writing, such as James Joyce, used slang. It’s one dimension of what slang can do.”
Dr Ferguson agrees, citing the number of creative writers that Northern Ireland produces who understand the power and ability of language in putting across a moment, or series of moments.
“In many ways, we have a number of registers coming through to us all the time.
“We have that historic mix of English, Scots and Irish, which means then that we can often have two or three words for the same thing.
“We are like the cliche of the Eskimos having so many words for snow; there are, it seems, lots and lots of words out there for ‘potatoes’ that we have.
“Certain areas will have a certain word for certain things and that’s a real strength. I think there’s a variety there and there’s a wonderful history to where those words came from. And even at times, I don’t think we’ve even grasped yet the opportunities that that has for who we are and what we can do and where we can go with that.”
Again, Ulster Scots is mentioned: a language so many of us use without even knowing. Anyone ever had a ‘boak’ after a foodstuff not agreeing with them or done ‘the messages’? My favourite slang word ‘hoke’ has an Ulster Scots origin. It’s fair to say that a discussion on Northern Irish slang cannot be done without looking at Ulster Scots and its continued impact.
“Often there’s not a lot of prestige placed on something like Ulster Scots because there is a perception that it’s bad language, or it doesn’t have a sense of value behind it,” says Dr Ferguson.
“But on one hand, you can trace Ulster Scots back into the courtly language of Scotland and you can also get the sense of the authentic place.
“There are bad Ulster Scots writers, just as there are bad Irish writers or bad English writers, or bad French or bad Spanish writers. But when it’s authentic and done well, it transports you to a real sense of realisation that this is really important and fantastic literature and you’re in the room.
“Whenever anybody questions me about the validity of Ulster Scots, I say go to Seamus Heaney and he talks about reading [poet] Rabbie Burns’ To a Mouse and ‘wee, sleekit, cowrin, tim’rous beastie’ appears in the first line.
“This really electrifies him because the word ‘wee’ appears. It’s the word that he hears at home in his kitchen language as he calls it and it’s also the word that miraculously appears in the world of art and literature and anthologies.
“I think this is when we realised that the very simple words we think we’ve grown up with, we’re maybe a little anxious to use them. When you see the possibilities for those words, there’s something that really brings us home to just how marvellous our language actually is. And actually how it connects us with lots of people in the country at times when there are things that don’t connect us.”
Slang has a special place in painting a vivid image of what it is we’re trying to say. It also gives us an insight into a specific culture and attitude. In Northern Ireland’s case, that we have multiple uses for the word ‘wee.’
“We all know how good a wee cup of tea is, a wee rest or a wee drink or a wee day off. These all have their meanings. It can be cold or be freezing but when it’s Baltic, we know exactly what that means and we know we’re foundered,” says Dr Ferguson.
“One of our great words, and I think there’s a difference between the town and city where it’s ‘scunnered’ or ‘scundered’. You can be annoyed and you can be frustrated, but nothing hits home [than] the sense of ‘I am totally scunnered’ or ‘I am totally scundered’ about something. These are things that we should protect.”
Language too is continuously developing. There are times too when a slang word enters the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) and becomes almost standardised, says Gail.
“Yesterday’s slang term is today or the future’s commonly understood term for something,” she explains.
“I guess that’s how language changes and evolves, through its users. You’re getting a people’s history of language use when you think about slang terms. All language passes through users.
“Every year I’m always interested to see what makes it into the OED — it tells you a lot about the way we speak now and how the dictionary has to keep up with the language that people are using.
“In 2022, ‘a chara’ entered the OED. So did ‘fluthered’, first used by James Joyce in 1927, ‘gaslighter’ and ‘vaxxed’. It’s great to see Irish English there and words that reflect what we’re living through.”
Similarly, Dr Ferguson says the ‘beauty’ of slang is that it’s often at the cutting edge of where words enter into common parlance.
“It often comes from young people so that there is a sense that if somebody like me is using the word, it has long lost its kind of cachet,” he laughs.
“But there’s a there’s a real sense that this is how words get born and taken into language. They’re used in some circles and in some groups.
“We all talk about going to uni now and in a sense, this is Australian dialect that we’ve picked up when Neighbours came along in the 1980s. Suddenly, ‘uni’ seems one of the obvious words to use because it’s been floating through media, but it’s loaded into everyday speech.
“Language is always a kind of magpie; it always throws up things for us to use that we’re not expected to use. Even terms that maybe in the past would have had specific meanings for specific groups, suddenly, this becomes widespread.”
The phrases we barely think about, so bound are they to our identity, are not just ours, however, they’re widely available for visitors to enjoy — on a sock or enamel mug, among other things.
Linzi Rooney is the owner of Born and Bred, a shop celebrating homeware and apparel with a decidedly local twist.
“I think it’s actually gotten more popular,” she says of the slang-adorned items.
“There’s more of a pride and a confidence that has built up from locals because of who we are and where we come from.
“I think that confidence has grown given the number of tourists who are coming into the city. They talk about how friendly we are, they talk about our hospitality and are genuinely interested in the history of the north of Ireland. I think then that our confidence has grown which makes us take a bit more pride in our kind of phrases.”
She launched the business in 2014 and her ethos remains changing the often negative attitudes about Northern Ireland, creating a culture where we’re proud of the places we call home.
From ‘up to high doh’ coasters to ‘a wee bag’ tote, Born and Bred is proudly Northern Irish and equally proud of our famous sayings.
“I knew locals would love it and if you see the amount of actual tourists we have coming into the store in Belfast — 27% of our tourism comes from Scotland and England,” explains Linzi.
“With the Americans coming over and they ask, ‘What’s “awk hiya love?”’ – which we have on our socks and mugs – once you explain it to them, they then love it and they buy it. So they’re running around America with a pair of ‘awk hiya love’ socks on with people asking, ‘What’s awk?’
“It creates engagement in the shop and it’s probably why the shop is doing so well as it’s creating that kind of dialogue with tourists in the shop as opposed to going in, buying something and leaving.
“It opens conversations which is brilliant.”
Top of the festive socks for 2022 was a pair with ‘alright big lad’ and customers still love ‘Ulster says yeooo!’ and ‘ats us nai’.
“Having tourists back last year and also cruise ships was definitely a real confidence boost for the shop,” continues Linzi.
“For the last two years before that, in and around lockdowns, you were relying on local trade which was amazing.
There’s no greater feeling than somebody coming from Spain, China, Italy, America, Canada, and really loving something with a local sign on it.”
How a brand markets items with such a local angle is important, she says.
“I was always very conscious that it’s how you incorporate this kind of slang with your brand, and create a brand that people want to invest in and it’s a lifestyle brand. When you do that and add a bit of Northern Irish tongue in cheek, it’s quite popular.
“It may not want to be a mug you’d have in your house but when you add the pink and enamel and people will take pictures of it up the Mournes or are wearing their ‘alright’ sock in a style that’s trendy and you can see yourself wearing it. If you’re able to tie those two together then you’ve got a good product. It’s not just your fridge magnet with a leprechaun on it.”
Many households live with multiple words of various things, giving a flavour of the melting point of cultures and nationalities for whom Northern Ireland is home.
“I’m married to an American so occasionally with our young son, Beth and I are in disagreement about the things we say,” says Gail. “Simple things like I’ll say ‘plaster’ and she’ll say ‘Band-aid,’ I’ll say ‘chips’ and she’ll say ‘fries’. He knows that he’s betwixt and between terms.
“Even things like ‘wee’ and ‘what’s the craic?’ There are phrases I would say that, in the mouth of someone who’s not from here, they sound ridiculous. You can hear people, and English speakers in particular, trying to accommodate themselves, ‘Well, hello, what’s the craic?’ Or even words like ‘scundered’ or ‘jammy,’ or ‘dead on,’ all these things that I say quite often.”"

prompt: How can I calculate the amount of variations on a 3x4 table?
answer:
The number of ways to select a team of three players from a pool of four players is given by the binomial coefficient, 

\[C_{3}^{4}={\frac {4!}{3!}}=6.\]

There are 6 ways to select a team of three players from a pool of four players.
